body_html:
Thinking about how to make HMC a first-class citizen seems like a great
idea and I'm happy to help design this. Naturally I'd have to confer with
my team prior to building anything, but I suspect they'd support this
effort. Our lack of nontrivial numerical integration tools has already
impacted the scope of other projects. Eg, the recently added Bijector <https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/contrib/distributions/python/ops/bijector.py>
API is limited to pdf and sample in the absence of numerical integration to
support mean, variance, etc.

On Fri, Oct 14, 2016 at 4:53 PM, Dustin Tran notifications@github.com
wrote:

From @davharris https://github.com/davharris:

I was wondering if you could expand on what TF needs to add/change to be
suitable as a probabilistic modeling language?

The notion of a random variable.

Yes this is something I've been an advocate of for some time. Having said
that, I wonder if StochasticTensor (ST) isn't all that we need to support
HMC? Can you imagine needing something from ST that isn't there or worse,
that would be hard to add?

For our purposes, an RV is probably overkill--efficiently supporting a
sigma-algebra is probably generally impossible. I wonder if we really just
need the ability to compute densities and generate random variates? (This
is essentially what ST offers.)

I think the real trick is that we need the variates to have context, ie,
use this particular random draw at this stage and use a different draw at a
different stage. However this can be solved be requiring the second draw
to be a different ST (despite having possibly the same parametrization).
There may be some performance cost here though, particularly wrt the size
of the constructed graph.
